title: Roche family sells Morisset assets for $27m
text:
It closed in December 2012 after failing to capitalise on its early strong trading. It is currently housing a storage facility.

Local agents has estimated the warehouse alone, which cost $7 million to build, is now worth $10 million.

It's understood there are plans to sell the DA-approved land component once the deal had settled.

Mr Lambess said he's planning to hold on to the warehouse and look at re-purposing it with the council's approval.

"I'm a local and I believe in the potential of the area," he said.

"This is a phenomenal building in an excellent location. It's just been used for self-storage and I want to turn it into something that would make a difference to the community as a whole."

Adam Leacy from Commercial Collective said that the property is the last of its kind in the Morisset Business Park.

"It's a unique asset," he said. "I think Paul (Lambess) has the foresight to see potential in a relatively untouched asset. It was just sitting there totally underutilised."

Advertisement

Newcastle-based Winarch Capital had recently completed a 30-lot commercial land subdivision within the Morisset Business Park which they've sold all but one lot according to selling agent Ben Curran of Colliers International.

Winarch's most ambitious project to date is the proposed $235 million redevelopment of the 50 years old Morisset Golf Course, to be known as Cedar Mill, which would see a mix of outdoor concert venue, camping grounds and seniors housing.

The Roche Group have extensive holdings in the Hunter Valley, including the Hunter Valley Garden, live concert venue Roche Estate and Harrigan's Irish Pub.

The Roche family are substantial property investors, valued on this year’s Australian Financial Review Rich List at $1.42 billion.
description: Rich listers Bill and Imelda Roche had sold all their industrial property assets in Morisset, Lake Macquarie for about $27 million.
